title: Pro Bankruptcy Briefing: Junk Debt on Way to Record Year; Theranos Trial Supplies New Details
text:
Junk-debt sales soar toward record year. The $3 trillion market for low-rated companies' debt is having its best year ever, powered by a rebounding economy and investors' demand for any extra yield. The record issuance marks a notable rebound from March 2020, when investors' worries about widespread bankruptcies and defaults sent prices for low-rated debt slumping. Now, low interest rates and a stimulus-fueled economic rebound that has supported companies with weaker credit ratings have boosted the appeal of riskier debt.

What the Elizabeth Holmes trial is revealing about Theranos. While much of Theranos Inc.'s story has been closely chronicled by The Wall Street Journal and others, the trial of the company's founder has revealed new details about its losses, its fundraising and the lengths prosecutors say it went to deceive its partners.

Bankruptcy

Kyrgyzstan blocked from London gold trading over missing bars. The organization that oversees London's gold trading blocked metal mined in Kyrgyzstan from entering the city's market, dealing a blow to the central Asian nation's bullion-dependent economy. Centerra is locked in a dispute with the Kyrgyz government over control of Kumtor, a high-altitude gold mine in Central Asia's Tien Shan mountains that was taken over by authorities in the former Soviet Republic in May. Centerra then placed its Kumtor operations under bankruptcy protection in New York.

CityLift Parking files bankruptcy, blaming unprofitable work. CityLift Parking LLC has filed for bankruptcy, saying it was behind on payments to vendors as a result of several unprofitable jobs and delays caused by the Covid-19 pandemic. The Dallas-based company designs, installs and services automated parking lifts intended to save space and reduce the cost of building parking. Unsecured creditors in its chapter 11 include Dundon Capital Partners, owed $6 million. CityLift lists liabilities of $10 million to $50 million, and assets of $1 million to $10 million. — Becky Yerak

Sale process approved for New Hampshire's Hillside Village. Hillside Village, a bankrupt retirement community in Keene, N.H., won court approval for a sale process that will begin with a $33M lead offer from Covenant Living Communities & Services. Judge Bruce Harwood signed off on the bid procedures at a hearing Friday in the U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Concord, NH.Prospect-Woodward Home, doing business as Hillside Village, filed for bankruptcy last month, saying difficulties in meeting its debt obligations are due partly to stress that the pandemic has put on the senior housing industry. It also said construction problems at the community have hurt its finances. — Becky Yerak

International

How Beijing's debt clampdown shook real-estate giant Evergrande. In a risky race against time that ran for two decades, China Evergrande Group turned billions of dollars in borrowed money into the dream of homeownership for millions of Chinese citizens. Now years of aggressive borrowing have collided with Beijing's crackdown on debt, leaving the giant developer on the brink of collapse.

"It would send the wrong message if [authorities] were to step in at this stage to prevent a default."

— Julian Evans-Pritchard, senior China economist at Capital Economics.

In Other News

The last remaining Sears in New York City is closing, opening a parcel the size of a city block in Brooklyn for redevelopment. (The City)

Former high-powered attorney Tom Girardi has moved out of his multimillion-dollar mansion in Los Angeles and into a senior living facility amid his mounting legal troubles. (New York Post)

Retailers are rethinking their presence in pandemic-battered Manhattan as the Delta variant of the coronavirus delays plans by many companies to bring employees back to offices en masse. (New York Times)

Johnson & Johnson will urge a judge on Monday to disqualify certain votes in favor of a reorganization plan proposed by its former talc supplier, saying the votes were improperly changed in an attempt to secure necessary creditor support for the deal. (Reuters)

The California Supreme Court pressed state power regulators for more information about communications between the leader of the California Public Utilities Commission and top officials in Gov. Gavin Newsom's administration about the bailout of state utility PG&E. (ABC10)

Analysts at Bank of America downgraded the stock of two newcomers, Lordstown Motors Corp. and Fisker Inc., saying that competition among auto makers is "fierce." (MarketWatch)

The wave of bankruptcies that hit the oil industry is exacerbating the environmental fallout from Hurricane Ida. (E&E News)

Another retired Buffalo Diocese priest has been put on administrative leave after a claim in the diocese's Chapter 11 bankruptcy case. (Buffalo News)
